message.content:
Step 1: Calculate the Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio  
• From the cash flow statement, the Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities is –2,868,695.86.  
• From the income statement, the Net Profit is 56,497.85.  
• Ratio = Operating Cash Flow / Net Income = –2,868,695.86 / 56,497.85 ≈ –50.80  

Step 2: Calculate the Current Assets Turnover Ratio  
• From the income statement, the Total Revenue is 547,392.30.  
• From the balance sheet, the Total Current Assets (end) is 13,190,375.83.  
• Ratio = Total Revenue / Total Current Assets = 547,392.30 / 13,190,375.83 ≈ 0.0415, which rounds to approximately 0.04  

Step 3: Calculate the Quick Ratio  
• Quick Assets include Cash on Hand, Bank Deposits, Interest Receivable, and Accounts Receivable.  
  Cash on Hand = 2,179,154.14  
  Bank Deposits = 2,952,150.00  
  Interest Receivable = 9,881.70  
  Accounts Receivable = 200,359.99  
  Sum of Quick Assets = 2,179,154.14 + 2,952,150.00 + 9,881.70 + 200,359.99 = 5,341,545.83  
• Total Current Liabilities (end) from the balance sheet is 5,042,389.63.  
• Quick Ratio = Quick Assets / Current Liabilities = 5,341,545.83 / 5,042,389.63 ≈ 1.0587, which rounds to about 1.06  

Thus, the solution is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio": "-50.80",
    "Current Assets Turnover Ratio": "0.04",
    "Quick Ratio": "1.06"
  }
}
